key_points: Use-of-force expert John Black testified at a pretrial hearing that Kyle Rittenhouse's decisions to shoot three people during a Wisconsin protest were justified.
Black outlined that the men Rittenhouse shot had attacked him and tried to take his gun.
The expert's testimony offers a preview of the defense strategy for Rittenhouse's trial set to begin next month.
Rittenhouse, 17 at the time, went to Kenosha in response to a militia's call to protect businesses during protests sparked by the police shooting of Jacob Blake.
Rittenhouse is charged with multiple counts, including homicide and being a minor in possession of a firearm.
Defense attorney Mark Richards seeks to have Black testify at the trial, subject to Judge Bruce Schroeder's approval.
Prosecutors question Black's expertise on civilian use of force and challenge the justification of lethal force without a gun.
The judge denied a defense request to drop the weapons possession charge against Rittenhouse, citing unclear statutes.
Prosecution's request to prevent media from broadcasting or publishing images of witnesses' faces was also denied.
Rittenhouse has become a polarizing figure, drawing support from conservatives as a patriot and criticism from liberals and activists as a domestic terrorist.
